A310: Two engines mounted under the wings
T-tail configuration (horizontal stabilizer mounted at the top of the vertical stabilizer)
Shorter fuselage in comparison to similar aircraft like the A300
Winglets or wingtip devices (in some models)
Airbus branding and model-specific livery (if visible)
A320: Two engines mounted under the wings
A slightly curved, upward wingtip (often equipped with winglets or sharklets)
A relatively short and wide fuselage
A single vertical stabilizer (tail fin) with the Airbus logo or airline livery
Retractable landing gear with main gear consisting of two sets of wheels each and a nose gear with dual wheels
Four cabin doors on each side (two forward, two aft)
Often seen with a distinct Airbus nose shape (rounded and slightly bulbous)
The designation "A320" or airline-specific livery markings
A330: two engines mounted under the wings
distinctive winglets at the tips of the wings
a single vertical stabilizer (tail fin) with the airline's logo
typically has four or five doors per side (depending on the variant)
a wide fuselage with two passenger aisles inside
usually displays airline livery and registration number on the fuselage
windows evenly spaced along the fuselage
A340: four-engine layout (two engines on each wing)
two sets of landing gear on the wings and a set on the fuselage
“Airbus A340” marking or logo near the front
high tail fin with a streamlined design
A380: four engines mounted under the wings
a wide and prominent tail fin
typically white or silver with airline livery
multiple sets of landing gear wheels
spacious windows in a double-deck configuration
ATR-42: propeller engines mounted under the wings
landing gear with wheels visible on both the front and rear
typically white or silver with airline livery
small passenger windows along the side
ATR-72: Distinctive circular windows along the fuselage
Two-bladed or six-bladed propellers depending on the model
Typically white or with airline-specific livery
An-12: Four propeller engines mounted on the wings
Tapered fuselage with a rear loading ramp
Square or rectangular windows along the fuselage
Often painted in military or cargo airline livery
Short, blunted nose compared to some other aircraft types
External bracing on the empennage (tail section)
BAE 146: Four turbofan engines mounted on wings
High, T-tail (tailplane mounted atop the vertical stabilizer)
Distinctive, short fuselage with a pronounced curve towards the rear
Swept wings with moderate dihedral angle
Bulging fuselage just above and behind the cockpit area
Multiple passenger windows along the fuselage
BAE-125: twin engines mounted on the rear fuselage
often white with various accent colors or company logos
Beechcraft 1900: typically white with blue, red, or other accent stripes
distinctive winglets at the tips of the wings
landing gear which may be extended or retracted
Boeing 707: four turbofan engines, typically mounted under the wings
swept-back wings with a noticeable dihedral angle
a long fuselage with a cylindrical shape
T-tail design (horizontal stabilizer mounted at the top of the vertical stabilizer)
multiple cabin windows running along the sides of the fuselage
retractable landing gear with multiple wheels
a distinct nose with a slightly pointed or rounded shape
airline livery or logo often visible on the fuselage and tail
Boeing 717: engines mounted at the rear of the fuselage

distinctive nose shape, typical of the Boeing design
usually a single-aisle configuration with five or six doors along the fuselage
winglets at the tips of the wings (optional)
relatively small landing gear compared to larger Boeing aircraft
number "717" or airline-specific livery/logo on the tail or fuselage
Boeing 727: one engine at the base of the vertical stabilizer (tail)
two engines mounted on either side of the rear fuselage
T-tail configuration with a high-mounted horizontal stabilizer
distinctive "hump" at the base of the vertical stabilizer due to the central engine's S-duct
multiple passenger windows along the fuselage
Boeing 737: swept-back wings with winglets (on newer models)
distinctive nose shape with a relatively blunt tip
generally short to medium length compared to larger aircraft like the Boeing 747
noticeable horizontal stabilizers and vertical fin at the tail
landing gear with wheels that retract into the fuselage and wings
several windows along the fuselage in a straight row
often branded with airline livery and logos
Boeing 747: hump on the upper deck (distinctive upper deck extension)
four jet engines mounted on the wings
large wingspan with a slight upward curve
Boeing 757: two turbofan engines mounted under the wings
high windows relative to the nose
typically configured with a 3-3 seating arrangement in the main cabin
Boeing 767: high aspect ratio wings with prominent winglets
fuselage with a wide body and distinctive nose shape
two large turbofan engines mounted under the wings
three sets of landing gear: two main sets under the wings and one nose gear
windows along the fuselage for passengers or cargo
distinctive cockpit windows with a slight downward slope on the sides
Boeing 777: two turbofan engines under each wing
six main landing gear wheels (three sets on each side)
two doors on each side of the fuselage

C-47: large cargo door on the side
markings and insignia indicative of military use
CRJ-200: Two engines mounted on the rear fuselage

DC-6: propeller-driven engines on each wing (total of four)
